qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I use my phone for work-related communications, like emails, HRMS portals, Google Drive, and Zoom meetings. Personally, I use WhatsApp, Instagram, a bit of Netflix, and my banking apps. I manage team rosters and employee documents on secured cloud drives. My phone is a bridge between my personal and professional life.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: No, I do not share my phone. My husband might borrow it to make a call, but he knows not to open apps or notifications. Otherwise, it is strictly personal.

qa.question: What apps and features do you frequently use?
qa.answer: WhatsApp, HRMS systems, Google Sheets, banking apps, and Instagram. I know they collect data, and I manage those permissions carefully. For HR documents, I use a secure vault app.

qa.question: Do you read app permissions before allowing them?
qa.answer: Yes, I check permissions whenever I install something new, but I might skip a few for non-critical apps like photo editors.

qa.question: How do you decide which apps to trust?
qa.answer: I trust apps with good reviews, known brands, and preferably those that are compliant with GDPR or Indian privacy standards.

qa.question: Do you delete content for privacy reasons?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete sensitive employee documents, payslips, or any salary details after sending them. I also clear screenshots with confidential HR memos regularly.

qa.question: What do you do before giving your phone for repair?
qa.answer: I back up my data, sign out of every HRMS app, delete financial apps, then wipe the device before going to an authorized Apple store. If I have no time to wipe, I postpone the repair.

qa.question: Who do you ask for help with phone-related problems?
qa.answer: I will reach out to Apple support or my office IT team. I never ask random technicians.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: My husband and my office IT team. Beyond them, no one.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep information private?
qa.answer: Yes, in HR messages, we use codes for employees or projects so that details are not easily exposed.

qa.question: Have you helped others install or use apps?
qa.answer: Yes, I have helped junior staff install HR apps. I always explain about giving permission carefully, especially camera and microphone access.

qa.question: Do you manage app permissions actively?
qa.answer: Yes, I monitor permissions and remove camera or mic access for apps I rarely use.

qa.question: How do you respond to warning messages from apps?
qa.answer: I take them seriously. I verify them on the App Store or by asking IT.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you allow access to contacts or media?
qa.answer: I know that when I allow contact or media access, those files could sync to external servers.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair due to privacy concerns?
qa.answer: Yes, because there is employee data on my phone. I never leave it without wiping or signing out of accounts.

qa.question: Has anyone ever accessed your data during repair without permission?
qa.answer: No, because I take every step to wipe data first.

qa.question: Do you use a lock screen or additional security?
qa.answer: Yes – Face ID, plus a 6-digit passcode, and my WhatsApp has an extra fingerprint lock.

qa.question: Do you prefer local or foreign apps?
qa.answer: I use whichever app is transparent with its privacy policy and well-known. I do not blindly prefer local or foreign.

qa.question: Who helps you when you don’t understand phone settings?
qa.answer: My husband and the office IT team.

qa.question: Do people around you influence your online safety practices?
qa.answer: My office has cybersecurity trainings, which influence me a lot to follow proper practices.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I back up, sign out of HRMS and bank apps, wipe everything, then only take it to an authorized center. Otherwise I delay repairs.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my husband borrows it, I make sure I close all HR apps before handing over.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I check the developer, permissions, reviews, and only then install. I avoid any random app links from WhatsApp.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I help my father-in-law install pension apps, but I carefully check permissions and explain how to deny unnecessary ones.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: If someone’s notification pops up, I ignore it and just use what I need.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I remove iCloud, remove all user data, factory reset, and check Find My iPhone is off before giving it to anyone.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I check the cloud trash bin regularly and permanently delete sensitive files.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: If I must use free WiFi, I avoid anything HR or banking-related and use a VPN.
scenarios.Emergency Bank Transfer: I confirm on a video call with the person before sending money.
